repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Decentralization and Competitiveness
            Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Decentralization and Competitiveness
            Development Policy Loan Project (DCDPL) of Peru is comprised
            of 3 programs. Program 1, Programmatic Decentralization and
            Competitiveness SAL, had the following ratings: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low to
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Program 2, Second PROGRAMATIC
            REFORM FOR GROWTH Project had the following ratings:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            low to negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Program 3, Third
            Programmatic Decentralization and Competitiveness
            Development Policy Loan had the following ratings: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low to
            negligible, Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned
            included: 1) Operations designed for middle income countries
            with highly skilled government staff and were first
            generation reforms have been already implemented, need to
            place strong emphasis in building the program in a
            participatory and consultative way. The achievements of the
            DCDPL series can be attributed to a number of reasons: (a)
            the reforms were not imposed by the Bank but rather demand
            driven by the beneficiaries; (b) there was a consensus among
            civil society in favor of decentralization; (c) there was a
            strong lead agency in the MEF to spearhead the process; (d)
            Peru drew from the Bank's global experience with
            decentralization and competitiveness; (e) the reform program
            was designed and implemented gradually; (f) Peru already had
            the legal framework within which other reforms could be
            implemented; and (g) the process of change was taken as a
            national project; 2) The DCDPL series drew on a wide range
            of analytical work undertaken by the Bank, as well as other
            analytical work carried out by the Government or research
            institutions; and 3) Another key lesson is that the program
            had built in at the onset a degree of flexibility that
            allowed accommodating to evolving priorities and needs of
            the country.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Third Programmatic Decentralization
            and Competitiveness Development Policy Loan (DPL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Programmatic Decentralization
            and Competitiveness Development Policy Loan Project will
            continue supporting ongoing efforts by the Government,
            through three specific objectives: 1) protection of the
            country's fiscal sustainability during Peru's
            transition to a more decentralized state; 2) strengthened
            management, and fiscal capacity at sub-national levels,
            towards the progressive increase in services delivery; and,
            3) supporting the creation of improved regulatory and
            investment environment climate, to increase the
            country's competitiveness, with a strong focus on
            export promotion, and regional development. While the
            project will help reduce poverty through the promotion of a
            fiscally sustained decentralization, and competitiveness
            program, it is subject to two main risks: a) program
            sustainability, and, b) macroeconomic stability. First, the
            continuity of program policies is supported by a number of
            other multilateral, and bilateral agencies, including the
            Inter-American Development Bank (IADB), and the United
            States Agency for International Development (USAID), and
            Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW), among others.
            Moreover, the Bank has already begun discussions with
            government officials, as well as potential presidential
            candidates about possible follow-up operations to support
            reforms in these areas. Second however, the combination of
            higher than-expected government revenues, and the upcoming
            election cycle could trigger expansive fiscal policies,
            threatening macroeconomic stability and the country's
            debt level. The consensus in Congress on the benefits of
            fiscal discipline will limit increases in public sector
            expenditures for the rest of this administration.
